meanings.definition: Easily crumbled or reduced to powder when rubbed between the fingers.
meanings.sent1: The dry cookies showed their friability as they broke apart easily.
meanings.sent2: The old book's pages had a friability that made them turn to dust with a touch.
meanings.sent3: The sandcastle's friability made it a challenge to build, as it kept falling apart.
meanings.sent4: The ancient ruins displayed a friability that hinted at their long history.
meanings.sent5: The delicate flower petals demonstrated their friability by falling apart at the lightest touch.

meanings.definition: The quality or condition of being easily crumbled or reduced to powder.
meanings.sent1: The baker tested the friability of the flour by squeezing it in his hand.
meanings.sent2: The scientist studied the friability of the rocks to understand their composition.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked about the friability of the cookies, saying they were 'crumbling under pressure'.
meanings.sent4: The artist used the concept of friability to create a sculpture that seemed to defy gravity.
meanings.sent5: The construction worker learned to appreciate the friability of the soil as it affected the stability of the building.
